text: Hi, everyone.
My name is Barnini Bhattacharya.

And I'm really excited
to be presenting research
on allyship today.

Consistent with the theme so
far my colleague Dr. Samantha
Erskine and Courtney McCluney.

This research was very
much a labor of love,
and took a village.

And I want to acknowledge that
it did indeed take a village up
on my slide.

So allyship has really gained
traction in recent years

as being the magical
cure for addressing

issues of equity, diversity,
and inclusion in organizations.

And thus far, an
ally has typically

been defined as somebody who
belongs to a dominant group,

engaging in supportive
behaviors and actions on behalf

of a marginalized
group or group member.

Unfortunately, this
conceptualization of allyship

really takes a sort of one
sided view of allyship.

And it takes an unequivocally
positive view of relationship

that really positions the ally
as a powerful individual who

is giving help to a marginalized
individual who needs help.

And we do know that
this is not the case
in how allyship plays out.

Allyship is very
much a relationship

that is fraught and has
power embedded in it.

And we know even
well-intentioned allyship
is not always effective.

Examples abound such as
posting black squares

on your social media;
posting the pride flag, which

don't necessarily
help the communities
you're claiming to support.

To examine these
issues, we conducted

an inductive qualitative
study with 30 allied dyads

of women of color and their
nominated allies at work.

So we essentially recruited
30 women of color,

and asked them to
identify a peer at work
whom they considered an ally.

What was immediately
interesting was that over 1/3

of our participants nominated
other women of color

as allies forcing us to
expand our definition of who
can be considered an ally.

And where effective
allyship happens.

This is a lot going
on in the model.

But I'll focus on the kind
of Allied relationships

that our participants forged at
work based on gaps that we saw

in how allies were
enacting their allyship,

and the kind of expectations
that beneficiaries
had from them.

And we see that there
were different kinds

of relationships being formed
based on the gaps that existed.

The first was this idea
of fragile allyship, which

primarily consisted
of relationships

between white women
and women of color.

And these were relationships
where the ally did not

have a keen understanding of
what the beneficiary needed.

And often felt a sense of
insecurity and fragility
in this relationship.

As Chioma said, I would
like it if Liz told our boss

that Chioma came and
presented so that he
knows what it is I'm doing.

I don't think she would go to
her boss and do that advocacy.

When I try having a
conversation about that,
she becomes emotional.

And I spend all my time
managing that and telling her
that she's not racist.

Liz seemed to conceptualize
the relationship differently,

and said discussions of race and
racism we've had in the past,

she needs me as somebody
who's a safe space

to talk to because I'm
willing to engage and listen.

The second relationship
we identified
was paternalistic allyship.

Typically forged between senior
White men and women of color.

These often framed the
beneficiary as somebody

who was exceptional in order
to be deserving of allyship.

So Phoebe said, "He's been the
best boss of my career to date.
He was so supportive.

As a young Black person
who's a Black woman,
it's easy to be dismissed."

Patrick said, "I knew that
this was an exceptional person.

The more I heaped
on her shoulders,
the more she was never phased.

I handed this million
dollar project to her.

I was thrilled to be able
to do that because Phoebe

was so much more enchanting as
the face of the organization."

And the third was what we
called accomplice allyship.

We found interestingly
was typically
forged between women of color.

And so Charlotte, who is a Black
woman, spoke about her ally.

And said, "When I
think of Violet,

Violet is an East
Asian woman, I think

of going beyond because they're
putting themselves at risk.

She focuses on what I need
when she sees an inequity
and she names it.
Even if it puts her at risk.

And Violet said that I have my
own lived experience of dealing
with racism and sexism.

But her experience is
not the same as mine."

So she saw that there are
relational differences in power

and privilege despite
the fact that they
were both women of color.

It's not like I'm
ignoring my racism.
I saw the anti-blackness.

I just want to quickly
highlight that relationships

that were affective really
saw power as relational.

And acknowledged
power differences

between the ally
and the beneficiary.

And we're able to co-construct
effective allyship, and what
that meant.
Thank you.
